President Steven Muller
announced at a dinner last night
that $50,088,629 has been raised
in the Hopkins Hundreds
Campaign.
The goal of the campaign,
which began last February, is to
raise $100 million for the Johns
Hopkins Institutions. Trustees of
the University and Hospital have
committed over $10 million of
the funds, a "Trustee
response...unprecedented in the
history of the University and
Hospital,"- according to Muller.
It is interesting to note that
while a campaign is now being
made to raise $100 million for
the Hopkins Institutions, the
original endowment to establish
the Institutions consisted of $8
million.
Former U.S. Ambassador to
the Organization of American
States, and a Hopkins trustee, Sol
M. Linowitz was the principal
speaker at the Hopkins Hundreds
dinner.
Linowitz was also formerly the
board chairman of the Xerox
Corporation, and is now a senior
partner of Coudert Brothers, an
international law firm.
Introduced by Dr. Milton
Eisenhower, President Emeritus
of Hopkins, and honorary
chairman of the Hundreds
Campaign, Linowitz spoke of the
role of Johns Hopkins in society
.today, saying that Hopkins "can
and does bring in addition to its
educational and cultural
strengths, something which only
a great university can bring--a
sense of time, a sense of place, a
sense of the order of things and

recognition that the world was
here yesterday and will
presumably be here tomorrow.".
Linowitz also pointed out that
our age has been called the Age
of Science and Technology, as
well as the Age of Anxiety. "As
our scientific and technological
competence has increased. so
have our doubts and anxieties."
He continued, saying, "For one
thing is certain, it is that
advanced technology depends on
the eu educated man to create it,
to make it work, to keep it
running, to improve it...one
magnificent by-product of the
new technology could be to
impel us toward a far better
educated, and therefore stronger.
democratic society than before."
Also speaking at the dinner
was Alonzo G. Decker,.Jr. chief
executive officer of Black and
Decker Manufacturing Co., a
Johns Hopkins trustee, and
national chairman of the Hopkins
Hundreds Campaign. Muller
stated thats he was proud to
announce the progress of the
campaign, made under Decker
and Eisenhower's "dedicated
leadership."

in the Hopkins Hundreds
Campaign is with the intent of
devoting $30 million of the funds
to provide endowment for
student support, library funds,
School of Health Services costs
and renovation in various
University Academic divisions.
Twenty million dollars is being
sought for a $100 million phased
Johns Hopkins Hospital
rejuvination, and the remaining

endowment includes the 50
named professorships, in order to
bring to 100 the number of such
chairs at the University.
Muller mentioned that the
campaign appeal has so far been
made to those individuals,
foundations and corporations
having close ties with the
Hopkins Institutions. He
indicated that within the next
year, the major thrust of the
campaign will be directed toward
the metropolitan Baltimore area,
and then to "our general alumni
solicitation" the following year.

regulations and highly dangerous in

been a start made in allocating
spaces in the library for smokers
and non-smokers - perhaps a
similar method could be instigated
in lecture halls and classrooms, so
that those who asphyxiate after 50
minutes without a cigarette could
sit down-wind of non-smokers
while in class.
Common courtesy has failed as a
method of retaining the viability of
classroom atmosphere intact - even
uncommon courtesy does not
always do the job.
